WASHINGTON - Rep. Dave Brat (R-Va.) made the following statement after House Leadership pulled from the floor of the House of Representatives the American Health Care Act.  "Over the past few days, I joined with conservative colleagues in the House to negotiate in good faith and find common ground with President Trump and White House staff. Those discussions with the President were positive, constructive, and moved the legislation in the right direction. However, the initial construction of this bill kept the structure and architecture of Obamacare fully in place. Even my Democrat colleagues agreed this failed bill left much of Obamacare in place.  For the good of our country, I want to see President Trump and his agenda succeed. With more time for deliberation, I believe we could have, and still can, get conservative health care reform that lowers costs and increases choice over the finish line. Productive solutions were well underway and could have been reached with a few more weeks of hard study and compromise – they may have even attracted some Democrats to the bill.  My promise to my constituents remains the same: I will always follow my principles, work towards good policy, and listen to my constituents. That remains the case with my commitment to repeal Obamacare and find solutions to drive the cost of healthcare down. Health care is one-sixth of our economy and it is too big of an issue to rush through. On Friday, President Trump said Obamacare will fall apart and then we will be there with solution and an even better bill. I look forward to seeing his ideas and finding unity in our party so we can all work to accomplish real repeal.”

Yesterday I joined with Congresswoman Dina Titus to introduce bipartisan legislation in the House of Representatives to reform agriculture commodity checkoff programs. United States Senator Mike Lee and Senator Booker introduced companion legislation in the Senate.  Participation in these USDA checkoff programs is mandatory yet the management of checkoff dollars lacks transparency and accountability. Yesterday I voted to stop the Federal Communications Commission’s (FCC) most recent step toward an unconstitutional takeover of the Internet by supporting S.J.Res. 34.   The FCC's proposed new rules, which had not taken effect yet, were sold to the public as "privacy" protections. The new overly restrictive rules would have tossed aside the previous Federal Trade Commission regulations that already required Internet Service Providers (ISPs) to give customers the option to opt-out of any sale of browsing information.   These FCC rules were supported by so-called "edge providers" like Facebook and Google. Under the proposal, Google would still have been able to use your personal information to sell advertising while ISPs would not. They wanted a competitive advantage to make money from this information while the ISPs would be sidelined by government rules.   I am committed to ensuring personally identifiable information remains private and protected. However, I do not support the government choosing winners and losers when it comes to regulating the marketplace.

Last week the Congressional Budget Office released their 2017 report on the long-term budget outlook. This sobering report rightly recognizes the core driver of spending growth continues to be rapidly increasing autopilot spending. CBO projected last week federal spending on health care (excludes state expenditures) is projected to be $16.5 trillion over the next 10 years – exceeding the cost of both Social Security and the military. In 2047, major federal health care programs alone will consume all revenue from payroll taxes and corporate taxes combined. This is why dramatically rising health care costs must be addressed. The longer we wait, the more difficult it will be to correct course. If Congress does nothing, our children and grandchildren will likely face a crippling fiscal crisis.

It has come to my attention there is misinformation surrounding a vote I missed last Friday on a one-week funding bill. I wanted to clear up any confusion.  On Friday, I attended a White House signing ceremony for an Executive Order on energy. I was invited as the Chief House sponsor of legislation to lift the Obama moratorium on offshore drilling.  During the signing ceremony, the House of Representatives called an earlier than expected vote on what’s known as a Continuing Resolution or CR. That CR contained funding to keep the federal government open for one week while negotiations for a longer-term spending bill were ongoing. Unfortunately, while I rushed back from the White House, I missed the vote by minutes.  One Internet blogger mistakenly referred to this missed vote as abstaining from a $1 trillion spending bill.  Nothing could be further from the truth. The bill merely changed the date of the previous CR from April 28th to May 5th, which means it only spent 1.9 percent of the annual appropriation of $1.070 trillion. And I indicated in the congressional record last Friday, had I been present, I would have voted yes to give negotiators one more week to work on the larger bill.  At 2:18am this morning, negotiators posted a spending agreement for the remainder of the fiscal year which ends on September 30th. This bill will come to the House floor for a vote this week.   The spending bill will increase the deficit by $25 billion. It prohibits funding for the border wall. It does not reign in the EPA or defund Planned Parenthood. And it continues funding the federal government full steam ahead without any meaningful spending reductions or conservative policy riders. Frankly, it seems to fall short on virtually every conservative policy position.   I am still reviewing the 1655 page bill, but based on the summary provided with the legislative text I will have to oppose the legislation.

Planning to travel abroad? This year the State Department is anticipating a passport surge of at least 21 million applications, which is 5 million more than 2016. This surge is due to the fact that 48 million passports will expire throughout the next two years, which will lengthen processing times. Currently, processing times are 6-8 weeks for routine service, and 2-3 weeks for expedited service. While passport services has increased its staff and facilities, many countries require travelers to have at least six months validity, so it is vital to renew your passport now if it expires this year. My Freedom Caucus colleagues highlight some of the problems with taking CBO projections at face-value.    “Beyond short- and long-term budget projections, CBO has also proven grossly ineffective at forecasting consumer choices. Nowhere is this more clearly seen than the Affordable Care Act.   As the ACA made its way through Congress in 2010, policy decisions were made based on flawed CBO projections, such as the one saying 21 million Americans would enroll in the insurance exchanges by 2016. The actual number was less than half that, around 10 million, and the miscalculation was disastrous for consumers.   CBO also miscalculated other economic impacts of the ACA. For example, they projected Medicaid expansion to cost $4,200 per enrollee. The actual cost turned out to be to $6,366 per enrollee. It is easy to read the national news headlines and think Congress isn’t getting anything done. Bipartisanship and progress on key legislation to help our veterans might not drive up TV network ratings but I wanted to update you on a couple of items I have been working on to advocate for our veterans.  In February, the WINGMAN Act passed the House and awaits consideration in the Senate. The bill would eliminate the VA as the middle-man and allow certified congressional staff access to information from the VA regarding the status of a pending request from constituent veterans.   I sent a letter to the Secretary of the Department Veterans Affairs requesting that the VA examine the list of diseases linked to Agent Orange exposure based on a report conducted by the National Academy of Sciences.   In June, I introduced bipartisan legislation to codify current SBA lending practices to ensure over 76,000 veteran-owned small businesses in Virginia have the opportunity to utilize SBA’s export loan programs and are exempted from the up-front fees.   In July, I voted in favor of the VA Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act was signed into law by President Trump. The bill brings much-needed accountability and reforms to the Department of Veterans Affairs. Under this bill, the Secretary of the VA will have expanded authority to remove VA employees who are bad actors. Importantly, the legislation protects whistleblowers to ensure accountability within the VA.   Also in July, I supported legislation that passed the House to update the post-9/11 GI Bill that also eliminates the 15 year time limit on the use of education benefits for new recruits. This bill now ready to be signed into law by President Trump.   And with my support, legislation to fund and extend the Veterans Choice Program was signed into law by the President last week. This program allows veterans to receive private medical care if they are forced to wait more than 30 days for an appointment or drive more than 40 miles to access a VA facility. This fulfills one of the core promises from President Trump to take better care of our veterans.   As you can see, it has been a busy year so far. It is a privilege to work to care for our veterans and service members and ensure they receive the care and benefits they were promised. Please know, both Democrats and Republicans in Congress are working to support the men and women who have so selflessly served our country.

Big News: Yesterday President Trump and EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt kept their promise to the American people to support American energy independence by repealing the Obama-era Clean Power Plan (CPP). In what was a massive overstep of legal authority during the Obama Administration, the CPP would have imposed a huge energy tax hike on American families. All states would have been forced to shift from fossil fuels to using entirely renewable energy sources like wind and solar power by 2030. In Virginia, over 60 percent of our electric power is derived from natural gas and coal power – both of which would be completely prohibited under the CPP rule. The costs of compliance would be overwhelming – totaling an estimated $33 billion placed on American families. In comparison, the total annual revenue received by the Commonwealth of Virginia from taxpayers is $39 billion.  In addition to the economic price tag of the plan, the environmental benefits remain unproven and the legal justification murky enough to prompt the Supreme Court to intervene and halt implementation. I applaud Secretary Pruitt’s decision today to begin the process of repealing this unconstitutional regulation.

Today I voted in support of H.R. 3922, the CHAMPIONING HEALTHY KIDS Act which passed the House of Representatives 242-174. My office has heard from Virginians via phone calls, emails, and social media to communicate their support for the CHIP program and how it serves our 7th District constituents. I am pleased that Republican leaders brought this bill to the floor for a vote despite politically motivated delay tactics by Democrats on the Energy and Commerce Committee who objected to how this program is paid for. It was disappointing to see only 15 Democrat members of Congress support a bill to reauthorize vital health care for children, this should be a bipartisan issue. I hope the Senate will act swiftly to pass this legislation and not play politics with our kids.”   DETAILS: The legislation provides for five years of federal appropriations for the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) through fiscal year 2022. Ready to be signed into law: This week the House and Senate passed historic tax reform legislation and kept our promise to the American people. This bill is good news for Virginia families who will overwhelmingly see more money in their paychecks next year. Economic evidence suggests this tax reform is already lifting the stock market to multiple record highs over the past few months. According to consumer and business expectations, it will help spur economic growth to as much as four percent next quarter. Already many firms are sending in great news of increased pay wages and bonuses. This bill will create jobs and make our onerous tax code simpler and fairer for countless Americans.   Here’s what the bill does: -Cuts taxes on 80 percent of American Families -The average family of four earning a median family income of $73,000 will receive a tax cut of $2,059 -Significantly increases the standard deduction to roughly double, from $6500 and $13,000 under current law to $12,000 and $24,000 for individuals and married couples -Expands Child Tax Credit from $1000 to $2000 -Preserves the Adoption Tax Credit -Preserves the home mortgage interest deduction -Expands the medical expense deduction -Eliminates Obamacare’s individual mandate tax penalty

Tax reform is good for American workers. Here are just five of many businesses that will be giving their workers a little extra take home pay and reinvesting into infrastructure improvements, charitable investment, bonuses, and increasing the hourly minimum wage. It's great to see instantaneous positive feedback from good policy. Virginia families will reap the benefits of a robust economy.
